etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in William Sweetland Dallas (1824–1890). From scientific Latin filopluma from classical Latin fīlum thread + plūma; compare -o-

definitions: A type of feather resembling a fine hair, typically consisting of a long, thin shaft with a tuft of short barbs at its tip.

notes.text: Filoplumes are always found in association with other types of feather, and may act as sensors detecting the movements of the neighbouring feathers.
